column1: Thermodynamics;30;G-XEC-2022-11;MCQS;79;For a glass marginally below its glass transition temperature
column2: which one of the following statements is true?   (A) Glass has higher enthalpy than both the corresponding crystalline and liquid phases (B) Glass has lower enthalpy than both the corresponding crystalline and liquid phases (C) Glass has higher entropy than the corresponding crystalline phase and lower entropy than the corresponding liquid phase (D) Glass has lower entropy than the corresponding crystalline phase and higher entropy than the corresponding liquid phase ;" To answer this question
column3: let's consider the thermodynamic properties of glasses compared to their crystalline and liquid counterparts:

column1: - **Enthalpy (H)**: Enthalpy is a measure of the total energy of a system. The crystalline phase typically has the lowest enthalpy due to its highly ordered structure
column2: which allows for maximum atomic or molecular interactions that are energetically favorable. The liquid phase usually has a higher enthalpy due to the increased disorder and reduced packing efficiency. A glass
column3: being a supercooled liquid with a disordered structure
column4: will have an enthalpy higher than that of the crystalline phase but lower than that of the liquid phase at the same temperature
column5: assuming it is cooled slowly enough to avoid the formation of a crystalline phase.

column1: - **Entropy (S)**: Entropy is a measure of disorder within a system. The liquid phase has the highest entropy because it has the most disorder. The crystalline phase has the lowest entropy due to its highly ordered structure. A glass has a structure that is more ordered than a liquid but less ordered than a crystal
column2: so its entropy is higher than that of the crystalline phase but lower than that of the liquid phase.
the correct statement regarding the enthalpy and entropy of a glass marginally below its glass transition temperature is:

column1: - Glass has higher enthalpy than the corresponding crystalline phase and lower enthalpy than the corresponding liquid phase.
- Glass has higher entropy than the corresponding crystalline phase and lower entropy than the corresponding liquid phase.

column2: the correct answer is:

column1: [ (C) Glass has higher entropy than the corresponding crystalline phase and lower entropy than the corresponding liquid phase ]";C;C;1;

Material Characterization;10;G-XEC-2022-5;MCQS;98;A differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) experiment tracks the heat flow into or out of a system as a function of temperature. If the experiments given in the options below are performed at 1 atmospheric pressure
column2: then in which case will the DSC thermogram exhibit a spike
column3: either upward or downward?  (A) Heating 10 mg of pure Cu from 323 K to 673 K (B) Cooling pure water from 323 K to 278 K (C) Heating pure ice from 263 K to 284 K (D) Cooling a Pb-Sn alloy at the eutectic composition from 323 K to 273 K;"To solve this question
column4: we need to consider the thermal events that would cause a spike in a DSC thermogram. A spike in a DSC thermogram indicates a sudden change in the heat flow into or out of the system
column5: which typically occurs during phase transitions (melting
column6: boiling

column1: (A) Heating 10 mg of pure Cu from 323 K to 673 K:
Copper is a metal with a high melting point (around 1358 K). Heating it from 323 K to 673 K will not cause any phase transitions
column2: so we would not expect to see a spike in the DSC thermogram. Instead
column3: we would see a gradual increase in heat capacity with temperature.

column1: (B) Cooling pure water from 323 K to 278 K:
Cooling water from 323 K to 278 K takes it from a temperature above its boiling point to one below its boiling point at 1 atm. However
column2: since the pressure is 1 atm
column3: water will not exhibit a phase transition in this temperature range (it will condense at 373 K and freeze at 273 K). Therefore
column4: we would not expect a spike in the DSC thermogram in this temperature range.

column1: (C) Heating pure ice from 263 K to 284 K:
This temperature range includes the melting point of ice (273 K at 1 atm). As ice melts
column2: it absorbs a significant amount of heat without changing temperature
column3: which would be observed as an endothermic spike in the DSC thermogram.

column1: (D) Cooling a Pb-Sn alloy at the eutectic composition from 323 K to 273 K:

The eutectic composition of a Pb-Sn alloy has a eutectic temperature at which both lead and tin solidify simultaneously from the liquid phase. This phase transition involves a significant release of heat (exothermic reaction) and would be observed as a downward spike in the DSC thermogram.

column2: the correct answers are:

column1: - (C) Heating pure ice from 263 K to 284 K: An endothermic spike due to the melting of ice.
- (D) Cooling a Pb-Sn alloy at the eutectic composition from 323 K to 273 K: An exothermic spike due to the eutectic solidification of the alloy.

column2: the correct answer is:

column1: - Heating pure ice from 263 K to 284 K
- Cooling a Pb-Sn alloy at the eutectic composition from 323 K to 273 K

Material Applications;22;G-XEC-2022-6;MCQS;33;Which one of the following solvent environments will likely result in swelling of solid polystyrene?   (A) 0.1 M NaOH in $H_(2)O$ (B) HCl (aq.) of pH = 6 (C) Distilled water (D) Benzene;"Polystyrene is a nonpolar
column2: hydrophobic polymer. It is insoluble in water and other highly polar solvents because the interactions between the polymer chains and polar solvents are unfavorable. However
column3: polystyrene can swell when exposed to certain organic solvents that have similar solubility parameters to polystyrene itself. These solvents can penetrate the polymer matrix
column4: causing the chains to move apart and resulting in swelling.

column1: (A) 0.1 M NaOH in $H_(2)O$: This is a basic aqueous solution. Polystyrene does not dissolve in water
column2: and the presence of NaOH does not change its hydrophobic nature. Therefore
column3: swelling is unlikely.

column1: (B) HCl (aq.) of pH = 6: This is an acidic aqueous solution with a pH of 6
column2: which is close to neutral. Again
column3: polystyrene is not soluble in water
column4: so it is unlikely to swell in this environment.

column1: (C) Distilled water: Water is a polar solvent
column2: and polystyrene is hydrophobic. It will not swell in distilled water.

column1: (D) Benzene: Benzene is a nonpolar solvent with a solubility parameter similar to that of polystyrene. It can interact with the polymer chains and penetrate the polymer matrix
column2: causing swelling.
the correct answer is:

column1: Polystyrene will likely swell in benzene due to the favorable interactions between the nonpolar solvent and the nonpolar polymer chains.";D;D;1;

Mechanical Properties;21;G-XEC-2022-7;MCQS;56;Vickers microhardness (HV) of a ductile material A is higher than another ductile material B. Which of the following is/are true?  (A) Young’s modulus of A is greater than B (B) Yield strength of A is greater than B (C) Scratch resistance of A is greater than B (D) Ductility of A is greater than B;" To answer this question
column2: we need to understand the relationship between microhardness and the other mechanical properties of materials.

column1: (A) Young's modulus: The Vickers microhardness test measures the resistance of a material to indentation. While a higher hardness can be associated with a higher elastic modulus (Young's modulus)
column2: this relationship is not straightforward. Hardness and Young's modulus are related but not directly proportional. A material with a higher hardness does not necessarily have a higher Young's modulus. Therefore
column3: we cannot conclusively say that the Young's modulus of A is greater than B based solely on the microhardness values.

column1: (B) Yield strength: Hardness is generally related to the yield strength of a material. A higher hardness typically indicates a higher yield strength because both properties are influenced by the material's ability to resist plastic deformation. Therefore
column2: it is reasonable to infer that if material A has a higher Vickers microhardness than material B
column3: it likely has a higher yield strength as well.

column1: (C) Scratch resistance: Scratch resistance is directly related to hardness. A material that is harder will generally resist scratching better than a softer material. Since material A has a higher Vickers microhardness than material B
column2: it is likely that A also has better scratch resistance than B.

column1: (D) Ductility: Ductility is the ability of a material to undergo significant plastic deformation before failure. In general
column2: there is an inverse relationship between hardness and ductility. This means that a harder material is often less ductile than a softer material. Therefore
column3: if material A is harder than material B
column4: it is likely that material A has less ductility than material B.

column2: the true statements are:

column1: - (B) Yield strength of A is greater than B
- (C) Scratch resistance of A is greater than B

column2: C]
C;B
